question.text: Which of the following statements about special senses is correct?

answer.text: All special senses, except smell, rely on specialized receptor cells to detect stimuli.

explanation.text: Olfaction is the only special sense in which the receptor cells are neurons, and in this case, they are specialized to detect different odors.

answer.text: Special sense input is carried by both spinal and cranial neurons.

explanation.text: Special sense input is carried by cranial nerves only; the special sense organs are all housed in the head.

answer.text: Special sense stimuli are detected by the receptive endings of sensory neurons.

explanation.text: Most special senses rely on receptors that are not neurons but instead are specialized cells that detect specific types of stimuli.

answer.text: Special senses detect stimuli such as touch, pain, and temperature.

explanation.text: Those stimuli are detected by the general senses, not the special senses.

question.text: In olfaction, activation of G-protein-coupled receptors leads to the formation of __________.

explanation.text: The activated G-protein triggers the enzyme adenylate cyclase to convert ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP).
When G-proteins activate the enzyme adenylate cyclase, it converts ATP into another molecule. Therefore, ATP is not formed but is used as a precursor.
Activation of G-protein-coupled receptors leads to Na and Ca ion influx into the neuron via ion channels but not the formation of Na and Ca ions.
Odorants are the chemicals that are detected by the G-protein-coupled olfactory receptors and activate them.

question.text: Specialized epithelial cells that contain receptors to detect taste are called __________.

explanation.text: Gustatory cells have microvilli with receptors for taste on their apical surface. The basal end of each gustatory cell forms a synapse with the receptive endings of a sensory neuron.
Papillae are rounded projections on the surface of the tongue, which contain taste buds. They are not specialized epithelial cells.
Supporting cells provide physical support for the cells that detect taste, but they have no role in sensation.
Taste buds are not cells but small clusters of receptor cells and supporting cells scattered across the tongue and parts of the oral cavity.

question.text: Which of the following disorders might result in an inability to sense taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue?

explanation.text: Paralysis of the facial nerve might result in abnormal or reduced taste sensation, because the facial nerve carries taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
Trochlear nerve injury will impair vision, not taste.
Trigeminal nerve dysfunction will lead to severe, stabbing pain in the face but will not impair the transduction of taste.
Injury to the hypoglossal nerve will impair swallowing and problems with controlling tongue movement and speech. The hypoglossal nerve is not sensory for taste.

question.text: Which of the extrinsic eye muscles passes through the trochlea?

explanation.text: The superior oblique muscle travels from the posterior orbit along the medial wall and through a fibrous loop called the trochlea before inserting on the superolateral part of the eyeball.
The medial rectus muscle extends from a common tendinous ring on the posterior wall of the orbit to insert in the medial surface of the eyeball.
The lateral rectus muscle extends from a common tendinous ring on the posterior wall of the orbit to insert in the lateral surface of the eyeball.
The inferior oblique muscle originates from the medial floor of the orbit to insert on the inferolateral part of the eyeball.

question.text: The area of the retina that contains a high density of photoreceptors and enables us to focus on a particular object is called __________.

explanation.text: The fovea centralis is located in the center of the macula lutea region of the retina.
The optic disc is a portion of the retina that does not contain any photoreceptors.
The lens is a separate structure, not part of the retina.
The ora serrata is the boundary between anterior retina and the posterior edge of the ciliary body.

question.text: While viewing a colorful painting in a museum, you will mostly use your __________.

explanation.text: Cones can detect color, because they contain the pigment photopsin, which responds to wavelengths we perceive as either blue, green, or red.
Rods cannot detect color, but they are very sensitive and capable of responding in less intense light.
The pigment rhodopsin does not distinguish between different wavelengths of visible light and therefore cannot detect color.
The outer pigmented layer of the retina does not contain photoreceptors.

question.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes transduction in photoreceptors when light stimulates them?

answer.text: Photoreceptor cells hyperpolarize and stop inhibiting bipolar cells.

explanation.text:
The bipolar cells are freed from inhibition and
depolarize and stimulate the retinal ganglion cells.

answer.text: Photoreceptors depolarize and stimulate bipolar cells.

explanation.text: Photoreceptors do not stimulate bipolar cells in the presence of light.

answer.text: Photoreceptors depolarize and inhibit bipolar cells.

explanation.text: This is true about photoreceptors in the dark, but not true when they are stimulated by light.

answer.text: Photoreceptors hyperpolarize and inhibit bipolar cells.

explanation.text: When photoreceptors hyperpolarize, they do not inhibit bipolar cells.

question.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the auditory ossicles?

explanation.text: The stapedius is a muscle that reduces movement of the ossicles as a unit.
The malleus is the hammer-shaped auditory ossicle.
The incus is the anvil-shaped auditory ossicle.
The stapes is the stirrup-shaped auditory ossicle.
Ear wax protects the auditory canal from microbes and small insects.
Tears are secreted by the lacrimal glands, not the ceruminous glands.
Mucus is secreted by mucous glands and specialized cells.
Saliva is secreted by salivary glands, not ceruminous glands.

question.text: Which of the following structures of the inner ear is/are filled with perilymph?

explanation.text: The scala vestibuli is superior to the cochlear duct and continuous with the vestibule near the oval window.
The tympanic membrane is not a structure of the inner ear; it separates the outer ear from the middle ear.
The cochlear duct, also known as the scala media, is filled with endolymph.
The semicircular ducts contain endolymph.

question.text: Vibrations of the auditory ossicles are transmitted to the cochlea via the __________.

explanation.text: The oval window vibrates, causing the liquid in the inner ear to vibrate.
The tympanic membrane transmits vibrations to the auditory ossicles.
The round window is located at the end of the scala tympani and allows the fluid in the cochlea to be displaced, because it bulges out into the middle ear.
The auricle is the visible part of the outer ear that funnels sound waves into the external auditory canal.

question.text: The loud sound of a police siren will cause __________.

answer.text: strong vibrations of the endolymph and basilar membrane at the base of the cochlea

explanation.text:
Pressure waves from high-frequency sounds travel only a short distance into the cochlea and cause the basilar membrane to vibrate where
it is narrow and stiff.

answer.text: weak vibrations of the endolymph and basilar membrane at the base of the cochlea

explanation.text: Weak vibrations are produced by quiet sounds.

answer.text: strong vibrations of the endolymph and basilar membrane farther up the cochlea

explanation.text: Vibrations that travel farther up the cochlea to where it is wider and more flexible are those produced by low-pitched sounds.

answer.text: weak vibrations of the endolymph and basilar membrane farther up the cochlea

explanation.text: Vibrations that travel farther up the cochlea to where it is wider and more flexible are those produced by low-pitched sounds.

question.text: When stereocilia of the hair cells of the maculae bend towards the kinocilium, __________.

answer.text: stimulation of the vestibular nerve increases

explanation.text:
As stereocilia bend toward the kinocilium, the hair
cells depolarize and release more glutamate, stimulating the neurons of the vestibular nerve.

answer.text: stimulation of the vestibular nerve decreases

explanation.text: This will be the case if stereocilia bend away from the kinocilium.

answer.text: stimulation of the olfactory nerve increases

explanation.text: The hair cells of the maculae do not stimulate the olfactory nerve.

answer.text: stimulation of the olfactory nerve decreases

explanation.text: The hair cells of the maculae do not stimulate the olfactory nerve.

question.text: Which of the following special senses is NOT processed by the thalamus?

explanation.text: The olfactory tract carries sensory information to the temporal lobe.
Hearing is processed in the thalamus.
Vision is processed in the thalamus.
Taste is processed in the thalamus.
